title: Trump administration extends TPS for more than 200,000 El Salvador citizens living in US
text:
More than 200,000 Salvadorans living in the United States have been granted a last-minute reprieve to remain in the US for another year after the Trump administration extended their provisional protection.

El Salvador President Nayib Bukele made the announcement via his Twitter account Monday alongside U.S. Ambassador Ronald Douglas Johnson.

'They said it was impossible. That the Salvadoran government could not do anything. But we knew that our allies wouldn't leave us alone,' President Bukele wrote.

'We didn't want to share it before because it could have hinder the conversations. But after all, thank God, TPS [Temporary Protected Status] was achieved.'

U.S. Ambassador Ronald Douglas Johnson and El Salvador President Nayib Bukele revealed Monday that the United States will extend the Temporary Protected Status program for more than 200,000 Salvadoran residents living in the U.S.

People demonstrated in front of the White House in November 2018 to protest the Trump administration's plan to end Temporary Protected Status for people from different countries

The TPS program allows Salvadorans to stay in the US and avoid deportation proceedings.

'This is recognition of the achievements and good work of the government of Nayib Bukele,' Johnson said.

The Trump administration's move to end TPS for El Salvador and several other countries had been enjoined by a federal judge.

The program is set in place to provide humanitarian aid to people affected by natural disasters, war or other grave conditions.

In September, El Salvador agreed to work with the U.S. to limit migration crossing its borders and accept asylum seekers who tried to reach the U.S. border.

Bukele entered office in June and encountered domestic criticism when his government signed the immigration agreement with the United States. Critics thought he had failed to get the coveted TPS extension in return.

'We didn't want to share it earlier because it could have hindered talks,' he wrote.

El Salvador President Nayib Bukele shakes hands with Donald Trump during a September meeting during a break from the United Nations General Assembly meetings held in New York

Immigrants gathered at January 2018 press conference in New York to support the continuation of TPS for more than 200,000 Salvadorans living in the United States

Salvadoran citizens were originally granted TPS in 2001 following earthquakes in January and February of 2001.

El Salvador had been worried about potentially having to absorb thousands of citizens who had made lives for themselves in the U.S.

Deportees are often stigmatized in El Salvador - people think they must have done something wrong to get deported - and find it more difficult to find work and re-establish themselves in their native countries.
description: El Salvador President Nayib Bukele said Monday the United States government will extend temporary protected status for more than 200,000 Salvadoran citizens living in the U.S.
